title: "we hope some of the biggest barriers to finding the fun in league will be fixed"
body:
Yeah, no. This is a personal message from me to any Rioter out there who might read this.

You want me to have fun?  I will never have fun as long as my {{champion:62}} is incompetent and passive-less, and {{champion:91}} is still bugged and feel less reliable and/or slow compared to other assassins.

 I started playing this game because of those 2 champs, and damn I'm so unlucky to have them both in the gutter and out of meta for too long.

You sure you have your priorities, like reworking {{champion:13}} every season or two. But why don't we put some effort into working on Wukong?

Just because nobody/less people complain-post about them doesn't mean they should receive less attention.

replies.body:
One of our designers was looking at a few Talon bugs last week in some time between tasks. Some were proving pretty tricky - I'll track down where we landed on those last week. I know 1 fix for sure is going into this patch (his Q range will no longer be bugged), but there was also some weird behavioral bugs when flipping over walls he was investigating.

Wukong ended up getting put on the backburner for a short amount of time while we re-evaluated the function/success of mini updates/roster scope updates. We'd been exploring him around the same time as the Xin Zhao rework, and there were a few lessons from that release that we wanted to learn from and apply to some of the champions like Wukong that share some similar thematic space and gameplay desire for players (we've seen that Wukong has a similar fantasy that Xin Zhao players and a few others share). For the time being we have him on one of our short lists for the champion team designer to pick up when they're looking for an additional smaller scope project to take on while waiting on iterations for their main project. I can't promise any timelines as usual, but there's only 11 champions on that short list, so I hope that information is better than no thing. Sorry we've been so silent on Wukong, there just hasn't been much to share recently that would feel particularly great, but I realize silence doesn't feel super splendid either. FWIW I think there has to be a better passive for him, and I'd be really interested if we could make him less bound to lethality in order to be viable in a game. Right now if you can't delete their squishies quickly, you don't bring much to a team comp that you couldn't get elsewhere. (Wukong has been one of my higher played champions in seasons past).
tl;dr yes you're right but we don't care lul or we'll look into it lul

I'm just gonna go ahead and say what needs to be said, but i'll say it more nicely then this guy and hope to shed some light on why he's probably upset.

Riot: "we hope some of the biggest barriers to finding the fun in league will be fixed"

Community: "Riot.. YOU are the biggest barrier to finding fun in league of legends right now."

It's time to seriously sit down with all your teams and rethink your approach to the game.

* Stop catering to the needs of the few and start catering to the needs of the many, do not let the LC$ and the pro players dictate what is and isn't fun anymore. By doing this you have caused serious backlash towards the LC$ itself, causing a good portion of the community to hate the very idea of it.


* Reorganize your balance team. This is wildly talked about but you cannot ignore the backlash this team has caused. Your balance team is totally and utterly out of control and they need to be taken into another room and spoken to. Something is going on with them that's causing them to tear this game apart, maybe they have some personal issues affecting their judgment? maybe they are under stress, but from them its been nothing but bad calls, community backlash towards them is at an all-time high, you need to reorganize your balance team if you have any hope of fixing the damage they have caused.


* Reorganize your priorities. The one good thing you announced was making changes to botlane this season and we all agreed, but then you pulled a complete 180 and suddenly turned your attention towards mages and other things we didn't ask for you, you jumbled up your priorities and can't figure out why we are mad about it. 


* Have a talk with your skin team. The skin team does good work sometimes but with the recent community review of gun goddess misfortune and the fact that our feedback towards it was ignored outright, its very obvious your skin team is either burnt out or playing favourites. Skins help keep the game fresh and entertaining, though not as large to a  degree as proper gameplay but they do help reignite interest in champions and players. the quality of skins has decreased dramatically over the season, so you should have a sit down with them and ask them whats going on as well.


* Stop focusing on complex and overpower champion designs. We all know who's famous for this, CertainlyToxic, but he can have an entire thread dedicated to him and his champions another time. What you need to do right now is review what you're doing with future champions. You are making more and more champions that cater towards causing frustration rather than fun. whatever team decides what skills new champs get and how they work, tell them to go back and re-evaluate those skills, tell them to ask themselves "Is this skill something that would be fun to use? or something that would cause frustration?" you'd be surprised how many times the second one is picked I bet.


* Finally, and this is the most important one of all. **Stop ignoring feedback**. you may say you do not do this but you do, the only feedback you take into consideration is from LC$ pro players, look at the upcoming mana changes? Do you see how negative the feedback towards them is? do you see how bad the backlash towards them is? yet i bet even as we speak you are still trying your hardest to drown out our feedback and force them out. " Right now if you can't delete their squishies quickly, you don't bring much to a team comp that you couldn't get elsewhere."

That is all divers have ever done. It's almost like they needed their own class roster update to differentiate themselves from other classes, ESPECIALLY after the assassin update turned assassins into basically second-rate divers. 

What else SHOULD a diver bring to the table? A diver's role is to kill priority targets, is it not?

To an extent yes - a diver is intended to be able to get onto the back line and present a very serious threat, but currently it feels like unless WK is able to delete someone with E+Q+AA with Duskblade (and ult when he has it), the amount of tools he has left or opportunity for compelling decision making is super low. It leads to Wukong having some very high highs (when I win, I win really hard), but also some really low lows (if I lose early, it's near impossible to claw back into the game). I don't think we should homogenize his kit so that he just has a flat power curve, since variance in performance between games is important, but do think that it would be great to let him rely on more than just E+Q+AA, or E+Q+R. He's pretty binary in that way, but his kit doesn't let him do much else.
Even if you're not killing people, though, you're still knocking up the entire enemy team with R. I just don't see how he's more binary than a lot of other divers.
Don't other divers have cc on something besides ult?

Yes, but other divers don't have Stealth. 

Also, there are many assassins who have CC on something other than ult. {{champion:107}} {{champion:245}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:35}}

They sacrifice quite a bit for that CC though, in most cases, the exception being Rengar. Evelynn needs her Charm to kill somebody, especially early game where her damage isn't enough on it's own and won't get them to the R threshold. Leblance needs it a little less but if she doesn't land it there's a high probability they'll get away or her R+Q/R+W won't be enough to finish them off since she probably used W to get to them in the first place. Shaco is kind of outdated and he's played more Bruiser ish now than anything else, his box's have to be placed, they have an Arming timer and such so, yeah. Ekko is the only one who doesn't really sacrifice much but his is pretty difficult to land.

Most assassins with CC sacrifice, safety, kill potential or mobility when they have CC, which is a fair trade and usually ends up increasing their skill cap. The only exception being, rengar and Nocturn to a degree but his has a delay like all the other's.

What do you mean rengar doesn't sacrifice for that CC? He sacrifices damage, sustain or a cleanse to use his CC. And it's only a root. It doesn't prevent you from attacking back under most cases, anyways.

To be entirely honest, this is one of the things that we're not super great at. I wish we had the time to fix every bug in the game (or at least the major ones), but we run into a few reoccurring problems on that front:
1. Visibility - even if there are threads about important bugs we may not seen them
2. Repro Steps - even if there are reports, there aren't always clear methods for us to reproduce them so we can track down the issue
3. Time - as Beany mentioned, when looking at an allocation of value to time, delivering on new content almost always trumps taking time to fix bugs - especially when they can get really hairy really quick. We could hire more people to do this, or could allocate more time to bug fixing, but it would come at the cost of additional things being shipped - something that can be a bitter pill to swallow for a lot of people.

I've been trying to think of ways to at least make some progress here, let me know what you think of this as a tactic. Essentially, reception to the bug fixes from Quinn that were bundled into a patch 8.6 was really positive - though it also took a decent amount of time for the designer to round up all the bugs/QoL changes, make the fixes, get them tested etc. I was wondering if going onto each of the subreddits for all the champion mains and dropping something like a:

"Hey guys, as a community it would be great if you could build up and prioritize a list of bug fixes / quality of life improvements that you think would help make your champion feel better. I can't promise if/when we'll get to them, but if we're doing work on a champion, it would be far easier to just get to reference a list from the people that care about the champion the most as opposed to us guessing what fixes may actually help. If the community thinks something is important, and we know where to find it, it becomes way easier for us to actually commit to that work."

I think a good point to start would be a real bug tracker system, and by that, I mean a system that has the following features:

1) One central page for all regions and languages, in English
2) A standardized entry form (the one accessible from the bug button in the client is fine)
3) A way to upload media documentation (screenshots, videos) to _your_ platform instead of a third party service
4) A catalogue of all known bugs to search
5) Status tags like "new", "needs more info", "no bug / won't fix", "confirmed", "in progress", "fixed"
6) Type labels like "Typo", "Visual", "Audio", "Performance", "Skin", "Client", "Ingame", etc.
7) 3rd person participation, e. g. editing issues by other community members (i. e. non-Rioters) to provide additional information such as steps to reproduce or a video of the bug, as a form of cooperative bug reporting where multiple people provide different parts of a detailed bug report
8) Ability to vote for and comment on bugs, mark them as duplicate, blocking, etc.

Currently, the site we get directed to from the client is probably the best input form for bugs. However there's three problems with it:

1) I can't check whether my issue has already been reported. While I can sometimes safely assume "yes", I can't check the quality of that report. Either way, whatever I do, it has negative consiquences: not reporting the bug means any additional information my report could have provided will never reach you, worst case is that the bug was actually unknown before. Reporting the bug means any duplicate information my report contains will require somebody to invest time without any additional information gained from it.
2) It can only hold links, so if I had a screenshot or a video, I'm dependent on the availability of free third party services to provide you with that media. But actually I might not WANT to upload videos for League of Legends bug documentation to my private YouTube channel of high quality cat videos.
3) Once I sent the report, it's "lost" like a letter thrown into a letter box. Neither can YOU ask for clarification because you can't get back to me, nor can I see what happens with my report. All I can do is repeatedly check for the patch notes or check if the bug is still there.

And finally, for your consideration; many companies have had success by creating a dedicated schedule for bug fixing. During the development of Windows 10, Microsoft introduced "[Bug bashing days](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OBeNyiazyXc)", a day dedicated to fixing bugs, not developing any new content, where developers and dedicated members of the Windows Insider community were interactively working together to fix some of the most annoying bugs.

Fixing bugs in a game is like doing dishes at home. There's most likely always something more fun to do, but it's a necessity to keep everything going. Somehow, you manage to squeeze doing the dishes in your schedule. And Riot must somehow make it work to squeeze bug fixing into their content development schedule.

To be clear, are 2+3 why something like the current Diana q glitches aren't yet addressed even though they feel really bad -- too hard to figure out what's causing them, so too much time down the drain better spent elsewhere?

Since Riot plans on having big patch/little patch cycles, have you considered having one of the little patches dedicated entirely to bugfixes/QoL changes with easy changes like numbers if need arises? I don't mean to come off sassy or anything, it's a genuine question.

Also, the subreddit thing seems like it'd be helpful. I remember something similar a few months or so ago asking for morde mains to compile a list of bugs, so I guess it'd be kinda like that but with smaller lists.

It's one of those things that will never fully get resolved, bugfixing is one of those areas where riot most likely doesn't allocate enough resources/manpower to, and what little they have focuses on the new content (and the new content gets a grace period of about a patch or two of bugfix attention before saying "fuck it, let's move on to the next content in the pipeline").

I say this as someone who has lobbied for years-old jayce bugs to be fixed, some successfully, some with riot outright stating they would never fix)
